article.name: Algebraically closed field
article.body:
In
mathematics , a
field
F is said to be
algebraically closed if every
polynomial in one variable of degree at least 1, with
coefficient s in
F , has a
zero (
root ) in
F . As an example, the field of
real number s is not algebraically closed, because the polynomial equation
3x^2 + 1 = 0
has no solution in real numbers, even though both of its coefficients (3 and 1) are real. By contrast, the field of
complex number s is algebraically closed: this is stated by the
fundamental theorem of algebra . Another example of an algebraically closed field is the field of
algebraic number s.
Given a field
F , the assertion â
F is algebraically closedâ is equivalent to each one of the following ones:
Every polynomial in one variable of degree at least 1, with
coefficient s in
F ,
splits into linear factors .
The field
F has no proper
algebraic extension .
For each natural number
n , every
linear map from
F^n into itself has some
eigenvector .
Every
rational function in one variable
x , with coefficients in
F , can be written as the sum of a polynomial function with rational functions of the form
a/(x-b)^n , where
n is a natural number, and
a and
b are elements of
F .
Every field
F has an "
algebraic closure ", which is the smallest algebraically closed field of which
F is a subfield.
